title: Hezekiah's Deliverance
shortSummary: Isaiah 37 recounts King Hezekiah's response to the Assyrian threat led by Sennacherib. Through prayer and the prophet Isaiah's message, God promises deliverance, culminating in a miraculous defeat of the Assyrian army. This chapter highlights God's sovereignty, faithfulness, and power to save His people.
timeline: c. 701 BC - Assyrian siege of Jerusalem during King Hezekiah's reign

keyCharacters.name: Hezekiah
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah who responds in humility and prayer to the Assyrian threat, seeking God's help.

keyCharacters.name: Isaiah
keyCharacters.description: Prophet of God who delivers God's promises of protection and judgment against Assyria.

keyCharacters.name: Rabshakeh
keyCharacters.description: Assyrian official and spokesman who mocks God and threatens Jerusalem.

keyCharacters.name: Sennacherib
keyCharacters.description: King of Assyria who leads the military campaign against Judah but is ultimately defeated.

definitions.definition: An Assyrian title for a chief cupbearer or military commander, here the spokesman who taunts Jerusalem.
A coarse garment worn as a sign of mourning, repentance, or distress.
Heavenly beings associated with God's presence, often depicted as guardians of the divine throne.
A faithful group preserved by God from judgment to continue His purposes.

outline.heading: Hezekiah’s Distress and Prayer
outline.description: Upon hearing the Assyrian threats, Hezekiah humbles himself, seeks Isaiah’s counsel, and receives God’s assurance not to fear the blasphemous words of the enemy. This section emphasizes the importance of prayer and trust in God during crises.

outline.heading: Assyrian Threats and Hezekiah’s Response
outline.description: Rabshakeh sends a letter mocking Judah’s God and warning of Assyria’s power. Hezekiah reads it before the LORD and prays fervently, acknowledging God’s sovereignty and pleading for deliverance. This highlights faith in God’s power over earthly threats.

outline.heading: God’s Promise Through Isaiah
outline.description: Isaiah delivers God’s message of judgment against Sennacherib, declaring that he will not enter Jerusalem and that God will defend the city for His own sake and David’s. This section reveals God’s control over history and His protection of His people.

outline.heading: Miraculous Deliverance and Aftermath
outline.description: An angel of the LORD strikes down 185,000 Assyrian soldiers, forcing Sennacherib to retreat. Later, Sennacherib is assassinated by his sons. This final section demonstrates God’s direct intervention to save His people and fulfill His promises.

application: In times of fear and crisis, believers should humble themselves and seek God earnestly through prayer, trusting His sovereign power.
Do not be discouraged by the mocking or threats of the world; God is greater than any earthly power and will defend His people.
Remember that God’s promises are sure—He preserves a faithful remnant and works all things for His glory and the good of His people.
Trust in God’s timing and methods of deliverance, knowing He can act miraculously to protect and save.

keyVerses.text: And Isaiah said unto them, Thus shall ye say unto your master, Thus saith the LORD, Be not afraid of the words that thou hast heard, wherewith the servants of the king of Assyria have blasphemed me.
keyVerses.significance: This verse encourages believers not to fear threats against them because God is sovereign over all blasphemy and opposition.

keyVerses.text: Now therefore, O LORD our God, save us from his hand, that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that thou art the LORD, even thou only.
keyVerses.significance: Hezekiah’s prayer reveals the desire for God’s glory to be known universally through His saving power.

keyVerses.text: For I will defend this city to save it for mine own sake, and for my servant David's sake.
keyVerses.significance: God’s promise to defend Jerusalem underscores His faithfulness to His covenant with David and His people.

keyVerses.text: Then the angel of the LORD went forth, and smote in the camp of the Assyrians a hundred and fourscore and five thousand: and when they arose early in the morning, behold, they were all dead corpses.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s miraculous intervention to deliver His people from overwhelming odds.
